subs.text: @kidehen The only people who say that Twitter and FB are web 2.0 are the promoters of web3.

subs.text: @JRubinBlogger that's the susan collins defense. oops i was fooled again. but it obviously isn't true of her, how could she be so stupid to be fooled so many times, and honestly i don't think it's true of journalism either.
subs.rawText: @JRubinBlogger that's the susan collins defense. oops i was fooled again. but it obviously isn't true of her, how could she be so stupid to be fooled so many times, and honestly i don't think it's true of journalism either.

subs.text: @JRubinBlogger the rational view says that news is controlled by oligarchs, and they don't like democracy, don't trust it, and don't see any reason they should stick their necks out for it.
subs.rawText: @JRubinBlogger the rational view says that news is controlled by oligarchs, and they don't like democracy, don't trust it, and don't see any reason they should stick their necks out for it.

subs.text: @JRubinBlogger If you think it's far-fetched, it's not. In fact it's how our country was founded. Only landed white men had votes. Because the founders, who were of course landed white men, and many of whom owned slaves, did not believe in the fundamental value of everyone getting a vote.
subs.rawText: @JRubinBlogger If you think it's far-fetched, it's not. In fact it's how our country was founded. Only landed white men had votes. Because the founders, who were of course landed white men, and many of whom owned slaves, did not believe in the fundamental value of everyone getting a vote.

subs.text: @JRubinBlogger Why would it be any different today for the people who own the news distribution system? How else would you explain the content that flows through CNN, MSNBC (who are supposed to be the real journalism orgs).
subs.rawText: @JRubinBlogger Why would it be any different today for the people who own the news distribution system? How else would you explain the content that flows through CNN, MSNBC (who are supposed to be the real journalism orgs).

subs.text:
@JRubinBlogger Unremarkably, they see the Republican point of view as reasonable and they echo it. 

And even the most outspoken pundits won't say this, even if they know it -- because you don't bite the hand that feeds you.
subs.rawText:
@JRubinBlogger Unremarkably, they see the Republican point of view as reasonable and they echo it. 

And even the most outspoken pundits won't say this, even if they know it -- because you don't bite the hand that feeds you.

subs.text: @JRubinBlogger I learned this a long time ago, when a big news org was in the process of blowing up, and I knew a columnist there, and asked him why he wasn't writing about the blowup? Even better, why weren't any reporters, anywhere writing about it. Blank stare. A meaningful blank stare.
subs.rawText: @JRubinBlogger I learned this a long time ago, when a big news org was in the process of blowing up, and I knew a columnist there, and asked him why he wasn't writing about the blowup? Even better, why weren't any reporters, anywhere writing about it. Blank stare. A meaningful blank stare.

subs.text: @JRubinBlogger The meaning? I can't talk about this. Even though everything on his resume said that he would talk about it. That's the problem with journalism, there's a gorilla and dinosaur in the middle of the whole thing that no one can write about.
subs.rawText: @JRubinBlogger The meaning? I can't talk about this. Even though everything on his resume said that he would talk about it. That's the problem with journalism, there's a gorilla and dinosaur in the middle of the whole thing that no one can write about.

subs.text: I didn't coin the term web 2.0, but i didn't object to it either, because what we were doing was realizing the vision of the web from the guy who invented it, who wanted it to be two-way, that people wouldn't just read stuff on the web, they would also write stuff.
subs.rawText: I didn't coin the term web 2.0, but i didn't object to it either, because what we were doing was realizing the vision of the web from the guy who invented it, who wanted it to be two-way, that people wouldn't just read stuff on the web, they would also write stuff.

subs.text: that was my first impulse when i understood what the web was, that and "how do I create something for this?" luckily that was very easy, amazingly easy. once i saw that i started telling everyone that this was the future.
subs.rawText: that was my first impulse when i understood what the web was, that and "how do I create something for this?" luckily that was very easy, amazingly easy. once i saw that i started telling everyone that this was the future.

subs.text: so i'm open to the idea of tech being used for new things. so now there's this thing they call "web3" which better be pretty great because it says it's better than the web, right? it ought to have something to do with the web too, or why call it web3?
subs.rawText: so i'm open to the idea of tech being used for new things. so now there's this thing they call "web3" which better be pretty great because it says it's better than the web, right? it ought to have something to do with the web too, or why call it web3?

subs.text:
so i've been listening and listening and i still have no clue what it is, and how i would develop the equivalent of a website for it or a web app. 

all i here is a bunch of proclamations about how it's the future mostly by people who don't create anything.
subs.rawText:
so i've been listening and listening and i still have no clue what it is, and how i would develop the equivalent of a website for it or a web app. 

all i here is a bunch of proclamations about how it's the future mostly by people who don't create anything.

subs.text: so my opinion so far is it's a way for vc's to make their money without any technology at all, no need to employ programmers, or support users, just create new currency and get people to give them money for it.
subs.rawText: so my opinion so far is it's a way for vc's to make their money without any technology at all, no need to employ programmers, or support users, just create new currency and get people to give them money for it.

subs.text: how that is supposed to be the web, well i don't think it does have anything to do with the web, other than it's a name people can argue over and that gives their idea heat, and drives interest, etc.
subs.rawText: how that is supposed to be the web, well i don't think it does have anything to do with the web, other than it's a name people can argue over and that gives their idea heat, and drives interest, etc.

subs.text: it's just a more efficient way for vc's to make money, in other words. unless you want to show me a developer plan, for how to create a website or an app. then i'll have something to evaluate. but i honestly don't think such a thing exists.

subs.text: June 6
@codexeditor @phonetonote I'm not so sure. The deep think part is relatively easy compared to the getting-it-to-work part or the getting-people-to-listen part. ;-)
subs.rawText: @codexeditor @phonetonote I'm not so sure. The deep think part is relatively easy compared to the getting-it-to-work part or the getting-people-to-listen part. ;-)

subs.text: @codexeditor @phonetonote The basic idea is that there are outlines everywhere inside the computer. So why write a million shitty outliners, when you could have one really good one with all the right stuff hanging off it. Then what would happen.
subs.rawText: @codexeditor @phonetonote The basic idea is that there are outlines everywhere inside the computer. So why write a million shitty outliners, when you could have one really good one with all the right stuff hanging off it. Then what would happen.

subs.text: @codexeditor @phonetonote The getting-people-to-listen part is basically impossible. It'll wait until people want it. Enough people are fed up with all the bullshit Apple throws at their OSes.
subs.rawText: @codexeditor @phonetonote The getting-people-to-listen part is basically impossible. It'll wait until people want it. Enough people are fed up with all the bullshit Apple throws at their OSes.

subs.text: Yesterday I read the archives of my blog for August and September 2002. It's a pretty good archive of a project that started off as RSS 0.94 and led, a month later, to RSS 2.0. It's all about humans and interop, very little actual tech. :-) [link]
subs.rawText:
Yesterday I read the archives of my blog for August and September 2002. It's a pretty good archive of a project that started off as RSS 0.94 and led, a month later, to RSS 2.0. It's all about humans and interop, very little actual tech. :-)

https://t.co/6ZS6SdjcvS

subs.text: @judell, then a columnist at InfoWorld, said including namespaces in RSS 2.0 was an olive branch. All perspectives are valid, but imho it was not that -- it was a commitment made early in the process. When the format was frozen, it would be extensible. [link]
subs.rawText:
@judell, then a columnist at InfoWorld, said including namespaces in RSS 2.0 was an olive branch. All perspectives are valid, but imho it was not that -- it was a commitment made early in the process. When the format was frozen, it would be extensible.

subs.text:
VMWare question.

Running on Mac, inside Ubuntu 20.04.3, the mouse is off by a few pixels. When I point at something, if I click on it, nothing registers. Move the mouse a couple of pixels to the left and click, and it works.

I've tried rebooting VMWare and Ubuntu, no help.
subs.rawText:
VMWare question.

Running on Mac, inside Ubuntu 20.04.3, the mouse is off by a few pixels. When I point at something, if I click on it, nothing registers. Move the mouse a couple of pixels to the left and click, and it works.

I've tried rebooting VMWare and Ubuntu, no help.

subs.text: 1/3 I connected with people on Twitter's developer relations team today. They had a conference call that I dialed into, and the conversation turned to devs big wish for the Twitter API, that we organize the code so that from a browser-based app you can communicate directly with
subs.rawText: 1/3 I connected with people on Twitter's developer relations team today. They had a conference call that I dialed into, and the conversation turned to devs big wish for the Twitter API, that we organize the code so that from a browser-based app you can communicate directly with

subs.text: 2/3 twitter, without having to run a server app as an intermediary. This has always been a big opportunity, but now there's communication. I've been developing apps using the Twitter API since 2006, and this is the first time I've had a conversation with developers at the
subs.rawText: 2/3 twitter, without having to run a server app as an intermediary. This has always been a big opportunity, but now there's communication. I've been developing apps using the Twitter API since 2006, and this is the first time I've had a conversation with developers at the

subs.text: 3/3 company. Real progress. There's *lots* of untapped potential here, Twitter's service is an incredible network resource, and there are many millions of users. Lots to do, and I already have a next step in mind. As they say, still diggin! 😍
subs.rawText: 3/3 company. Real progress. There's *lots* of untapped potential here, Twitter's service is an incredible network resource, and there are many millions of users. Lots to do, and I already have a next step in mind. As they say, still diggin! 😍

@JoselinMane @TwitterDev @alanbenlee @ashevat @jessicagarson @knowaging @dmgerbino @jamie_maguire1 @MarieRLombard @CrisGuadarramaM @BMWeinstein7 @i_am_daniele @AndrewVoirol @isajorsergio I've been DMing with @ashevat and posting on my blog -- and thanks for the shoutout. ;-)

What he talked about and the other dev talked about is exactly what I see here and have been writing about.

@JoselinMane @TwitterDev @alanbenlee @ashevat @jessicagarson @knowaging @dmgerbino @jamie_maguire1 @MarieRLombard @CrisGuadarramaM @BMWeinstein7 @i_am_daniele @AndrewVoirol @isajorsergio I've been DMing with @ashevat and posting on my blog -- and thanks for the shoutout. ;-)

subs.text: @JoselinMane @TwitterDev @alanbenlee @ashevat @jessicagarson @knowaging @dmgerbino @jamie_maguire1 @MarieRLombard @CrisGuadarramaM @BMWeinstein7 @i_am_daniele @AndrewVoirol @isajorsergio There's a higher level API possible. It's not hypothetical and it will make development much faster and easier, and more accessible to developers (less of a hill to climb to get to Hello World).
